metadata.case_name: Members of Ladva Shrimali Shravak Bania Community v. Charity Commissioner, Bombay

facts.text: Jhaverchand Dahyabhai Shah died in 1916, leaving a will dated August 6, 1915. He was a resident of Vejalpore in the suburbs of Broach and a Ladva Shrimali Bania by caste, professing the Jain religion and believing in the tenets of the Swetembar Murti Pujak sect of Jains.

By cl. 7 of the will, directed executors to spend out of earnings of his shop every year during lifetime of niece Bai Jakore specified amounts on religious objects: Rs.100 feeding cattle Broach Pinjrapole; Rs.100 Jiva-daya Khata; Rs.25 flowers for Lord Rikabdev; Rs.200 food Shravak pilgrims Shatroonjaya Palitana; Rs.50 food pilgrims Girnar; Rs.50 food pilgrims Abu; Rs.250 cereals/clothes Shravaks/Shravikas; Rs.100 cloth Jain Sadhus/Sadhavies; Rs.200 education/food Hindu orphans; Rs.200 Jain Gyan Khata; Rs.100 feeding fasters; Rs.300 food/cloth blind/lame/crippled Hindus.

Additionally under cl.7, directed executors to give Swamivatsal feast (methi-dal and ladus) to members of his caste at 15 specified villages/towns in Broach/Surat Districts every year on Pajusan festival.
By cl.15, after death of Bai Jakore, set apart Rs.75,000, out of which suitable amounts to respective Khatas so religious acts in cl.7 continued forever.
Bai Jakore died on May 20, 1928; estate vested in residuary legatee Bai Chanchal, daughter of Bai Jakore.

Mulchandbhai (husband of Bai Chanchal) set apart Rs.75,000 on trust for cl.7 purposes, managed trust estate. Invested Rs.8,000 in 5% tax-free Govt Loan 1944-45 (income Rs.400); handed loans Rs.4,000/1,000/1,000/2,000 to four institutions discharging obligations for items 2,4,5,6 of cl.7.

On December 8, 1947, Bai Chanchal executed trust deed for investments representing balance Rs.67,000 + accumulation surplus/unexpended income Rs.25,796-6-8. Registered as public trust under Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950.

Trust deed provided unexpended accumulation Rs.25,796-6-8 for establishing/maintaining Nivas for housing poor/middle-class Ladva Shrimali Jains at low rents; balance for cl.7 charities except items 2,4,5,6. Trustees had no authority to divert for Nivas; scheme invalid; not carried out. Charity Commissioner challenged validity.

Subsequent accumulations of unexpended income. Swamivatsal feasts and fixed payments met up to Samvat 1999 (1942-1943 AD). Thereafter fixed payments made, but feasts not given due to rationing up to Samvat 2010 (1953-1954 AD). Samvat 2011 (1954-1955 AD) feast not given despite removal of rationing.
Trustees allege current income after fixed payments insufficient for usual feast expenses.

Charity Commissioner filed application June 3, 1955 before District Judge Broach under s.55(1)(b) & s.56 for directions to utilise accumulations for educational purpose. Trustees impleaded as respondents.
Pursuant to general notice, appellants and four other Ladva Shrimali Shravak Bania Community members intervened.

District Judge on Oct 25, 1956: Accumulation Rs.45,019-14-0 + Rs.107-2-0. Directed Rs.22,505-15-0 to Sad Vidya Mandal for 4 freeships/year (pref Jains Broach Dist, else Hindus), liberty to spend corpus for building/ hostel/ facilities; Rs.22,509-15-0 to Sevashram Hospital trustees for investment, income for poor patients maintenance/food/medicine; Rs.107-2-0 costs.
Appellants and two others appealed to Bombay High Court; dismissed, confirming directions.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Court can direct diversion of accumulations of unexpended income of the public trust under ss.55(1)(b) and 56 of Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950, for educational/medical purposes instead of original objects including Swamivatsal feasts.
Whether the trust is for religious purposes excluding application of s.55(1)(c), and whether Swamivatsal feast and other cl.7 objects are religious.
Whether directions under latter part of s.56(1) permissible where original objects can still be carried out, considering Ratilal Panachand case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trust was for religious purposes; funds could not be diverted for other purposes under ss.55(1)(b) and 56; accumulations should be utilised year after year for deficit in annual Swamivatsal feasts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss.55(1)(b), 56 Bombay Public Trusts Act; religious nature

respondent_arguments.text: Directions rightly given under ss.55(1)(b) and 56; Swamivatsal feast charitable not religious; not expedient/desirable/proper in public interest; accumulations for educational/medical relief.

court_reasoning.text: ss.55(1)(a),(b) apply to all public trusts including religious; s.55(1)(c) excludes religious trusts. Under s.56(1), first give effect to original intention if expedient/practicable etc.; only if not, divert under latter part.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No case made for diversion under latter part s.56(1); Swamivatsal feast expedient/desirable/proper for Ladva Shrimali Jains; wider public interest does not require subverting.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide if trust religious or if cl.7 objects religious, absent pleadings/issues/evidence; left open.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Judge found feast and several objects religious; High Court brushed aside.

court_reasoning.text: Apply cy pres: surplus/accumulations to original uses; increase amounts for surviving objects due to rise in prices; feasts mandatory as far as possible, even smaller if needed; invest accumulations, income to cl.7 items 1,3,7-12 and feasts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overriding intention: devote Rs.75,000 to cl.7 forever; trustees cannot defeat by refusing.

court_reasoning.text: Lower courts' scheme objectionable: disregarded feast as not in public interest; Sad Vidya Mandal not analogous to Jain Gyan Fund (not restricted to Jains/religion); hospital not in cl.7; disregarded original objects.

holdings.text: No diversion under latter part s.56(1); directions under first part to give effect to original intention via cy pres for accumulations.
Question of religious character of trust/cl.7 objects/Swamivatsal feast left open.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Religious trusts' right to manage affairs; s.55(1)(c) void for encroaching on religious freedom; amended to exclude religious trusts.
Explains cy pres doctrine: substitute mode if original impossible, consistent with general intention.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates public religious/charitable trusts; empowers Charity Commissioner/Court to direct utilisation of surplus/accumulations; excludes religious trusts from s.55(1)(c); cy pres-like diversion only if original not expedient etc.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments/decrees of District Judge and Bombay High Court set aside. New directions: Out of accumulations Rs.45,091-14-0 up to Oct 25,1956, set apart <=Rs.5,000 working fund; invest balance per s.35; half annual income to cl.7 items 1,3,7-12; half to Swamivatsal feasts; continue from original corpus income similarly; feasts every year as far as possible, carry forward if not.
outcome.relief_granted: Directions for utilisation of accumulations for original trust objects including increased feasts and charities.
outcome.costs: Parties bear own costs throughout, except trustees pay Rs.64-8-0 to Charity Commissioner and Rs.42-10-0 to opponents Nos.

key_quotes.text: "the right to spend the trust property or its income for religion and for religious purposes and objects indicated by the founder of the trust"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ratilal case, upholding religious trusts' autonomy.

key_quotes.text: "Looking at their interest, it is certainly expedient, practicable, desirable and proper to give the feast. The giving and taking of the Swamivatsal feast on the occasion of the holy festival of Pajusan, if not a religious act, is a meritorious act prescribed by the scriptures"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies priority to original objects esp. feast.

key_quotes.text: "If the mode should become by subsequent circumstances impossible, the general object is not to be defeated, if it can in any other way be attained."
key_quotes.speaker: court
